awd_titl_txt: Bacterial Swimming and Pattern Formation in Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
****Technical Abstract****
This project investigates the effect of long-range hydrodynamic interactions (LRHI) on swimming of a single bacterium and a group of bacteria in proximity of each other. At a single cell level, how the backflow influences the swimming behavior of the cell who creates it has attracted attentions from mathematicians and physicists. Important theoretical predictions were made, but they have not been rigorously tested in the laboratory. This is in part due to most studies so far used Escherichia coli, which have multiple flagella that are difficult to model mathematically and in part due to the difficulty in changing the physical parameters, such as the hydrodynamic load, over a broad range. Using marine bacteria V. alginolyticus that possess a single polar flagellum and whose cell body can differentiate into different sizes, these difficulties can be overcome. The marine bacteria also have other interesting attributes that can contribute significantly to this research, which include: (i) a tunable motor powered by the sodium ions in the fluid, (ii) a large swimming speed, and most importantly (iii) the available mutants that swim exclusively in the forward (pushers) and backward (pullers) directions. Theoretically the mutual hydrodynamic interactions between two pushers, two pullers, and a pusher and a puller are expected to be different. We use a state-of-the-art optical trapping techniques to measure these different forces quantitatively. At a macroscopic level, we examine hydrodynamic patterns formed by these different swimmers. Recently, there have been intense theoretical efforts in this area, resulting in interesting predictions for this type of "living" fluids. These include the prediction of novel rheological behaviors, nonequilibrium order/disorder phase transitions, and liquid-crystalline-like hydrodynamic structures. This research trains graduate students in the emerging field of biophysics. 

****Non-Technical Abstract****
It is a common experience that a mechanical disturbance in a fluid spreads to its neighbors with a well-defined speed, i.e., the sound velocity, while its intensity decreases with distance. A swimming bacterium can be considered as a local source of mechanical disturbance and fluid motion in the vicinity can influence the bacterium's own motion as well as others in its neighborhood. This is what is called hydrodynamic interaction and can be described by a mathematical theory developed by Lighthill; it appears to work reasonably well for isolated swimming bacterium. However, its application to a large group of swimming bacteria in high concentrations is not well understood. The effect of hydrodynamic interaction on swimming of individual and a large group of bacteria is significant because it influences their ability to sequester nutrients in aqueous environments and to form biofilms on surfaces; both are important for ecological and biomedical reasons. The project uses the state-of-the-art techniques of laser trapping to manipulate bacteria to determine mutual hydrodynamic interactions between pair of bacteria in different configurations. These measurements compare and refine theoretical models that make predictions about collective behaviors of large number of bacteria. Given the multidisciplinary nature of the research, students trained are in high demand in academia and in industry.

por.por_cntn:
My students (Yang Yang and Corey Dominick) worked hard on this project the past year while fulfilled their teaching duties in the Physics Department. Mr. Yang’s study of marine bacterial (Vibrio alginolyticus) swimming in a polymeric solution resulted in an interesting finding that for a certain concentrations of polymers, a bacterium and its surrounding medium can form a resonance state. The presence of such a state can be understood as a result of a feedback loop, i.e. a thrust force generated by a swimming bacterium in an earlier time reacts back to influence its motion in a later time. The oscillation is significantly enhanced when the feedback time matches the bacterial forward and backward swimming intervals, a condition that occurs only in a narrow range of polymer concentrations. We constructed a simple mathematical model that takes into account bacterial forward-backward motility pattern and the viscoelastic behavior of the polymer solution. We are very excited by this finding because the simple model is physically sound, and it has practical implications. In effect, a small bacterium of a few microns in size behaves like a micro-rheometer in this experiment, and the motion can tell us the micro-mechanical environment of the medium. The technique may be exploited to become a useful tool to study microstructures of biopolymers and films that are of medical significance.  

Mr. Corey’s study concerns the following three subjects: (a) bacterial self-trapping on surfaces due to its own swimming force; (b) developing a precision chemical delivery system for impulsive stimulation of bacteria and other microorganisms; (c) limits of bacterial chemical and temperature sensing. For all these studies, bacterial swimming and cell-body rotation near a solid surface are important, and their description depends on mathematical theory of low-Reynolds number hydrodynamics, a difficult subject when a surface is present. The bacterial self-trapping on a solid surface was discovered by Corey a couple of years ago. Based on this interesting finding, he showed that this phenomenon can be used to study bacterial responses to various external stimuli. Traditionally, this type of measurements was conducted using anti-flagellar antibodies that allow a flagellar filament to be physically attached to a solid surface. Corey’s technique, which we termed “a rotation assay without tethering”, bypasses the costly procedure and makes it possible to study a wide variety of bacteria of environmental and health interest. Combining the two techniques in (a) and (b), the latter to be discussed in more details below, Corey was able to address the fundamental question of detection limits of a bacterium to stimulus such as amino acids and a temperature change. His latest result suggests that gut bacteria Escherichia coli are capable of detecting 2-3 serine molecules in 25 ms. The temperature threshold is about 0.2 oC over about the same time interval.

The remarkable finding for chemical sensitivity of E. coli is not possible without the new experimental technique Corey developed. His chemical delivery system consists of a micropipette with a fine tip of less than a micron in diameter and a Pico-spritzer that allows a short pulse of a chemical to be ejected from the tip. In his experiment, Corey found that unless the pressures inside and outside the micropipette are carefully balanced, there is always a flow at the tip. By adjusting the pressure inside the micropipette, he could produce an inflow such that a micro-sized bead can be stably trapped at the tip. This effectively shuts off any flow into the micropipette and stabilizing the chemical concentration inside the tip. In effect he had made himself a micro-valve that can be open and close on demands. When a pressure pulse is applied to the micropipette, the bead and the chemical are ejected, opening the valve for 25 ms. Once the pressure pulse stops, the in-flow carries the bead back along its original path and plugs the tip. A sequence of these events are recorded and displayed in Fig. 1. Due to the low-Re number flow, the flow-lines are time independent and the motion of the bead is highly predictable. According to Corey, in a good day, a single bead can be used to generate several hundred pulses without getting lost. I was very impressed by his accomplishment, and at the same time marveled at low-Re physics that works so well in this experiment.
